Title: Why is empty set an open set?
Content:

The definition of an open set: a set S in n-dimensional space is called open if all its points are interior points.
AcceptedAnswer: It's vacuously true. All points $\in\emptyset$ are interior points, have a blue-eyed pet unicorn, and live in Surrey.

Okay, let's tackle this problem from Math Stack Exchange. The user is asking why the empty set is considered an open set. They mentioned they're struggling with applying the definition of an open set, which states that a set S in n-dimensional space is open if all its points are interior points. The confusion seems to stem from the fact that the empty set has no elements, so how can all its points be interior points?

First, I need to recall the precise definition of an open set. The standard definition in topology is that a set is open if every point in it is an interior point. An interior point of a set S is a point where there exists some epsilon-neighborhood around it that is entirely contained within S. 

Now, applying this to the empty set. The empty set has no points. So, the statement "all points in the empty set are interior points" is vacuously true. Because there are no points in the empty set, there's no point that isn't an interior point. In logic, a universal statement ("for all x in S, P(x)") is true if there are no counterexamples. Since there are no x in S (the empty set), the condition holds automatically.

Alternatively, another way to think about it is through the negation. The negation of "all points are interior points" would be "there exists a point that is not an interior point." But since there are no points in the empty set, such a point cannot exist. Therefore, the negation is false, which means the original statement is true.

Also, in topology, one of the axioms is that both the entire space and the empty set are open. This is part of the foundational definitions to ensure consistency in the theory. But the question is about why it fits the given definition, not just an axiom.
